content.description: Follow intermittent seams along the right side of an arete. Tuolumne-style crystals abound.
content.location: Obvious arete, high on the right side of the crag. Scramble over from "Lady Of The Lake" via a low-angle slab.

content.description: Short but good route on heavily-featured and colorful granite. The crux is turning the lip near the top.
content.location: Right-most of two routes on a large, detached block in the middle of the buttress.

content.description: Short but deceptively steep route in a vague corner system. The crux comes right off the ground but the route stays on you despite it's length. This one is kind of scruffy and could use some traffic, but is pretty fun regardless.
content.protection:
6 bolts, lower-off chain anchors. Stick clipping the first couple of bolts might be in order (there may be an

in situ

stick at the base).
content.location: Left-most of two routes on the large, detached block in the middle of the buttress.

content.description: Follow edges through an obvious black streak, then step right following seam with poor feet. The crux is passing the last bolt.
content.location: Lone route on a small block at the far right side of the buttress.

content.description:
Enjoyable face climbing up the center of the gently overhanging face. Â The climb has a moderate start to a thin crux on sharp crimps before some jugs in the roof break. After the break, long and techy moves keep you engaged until the final jug rail below the chains.

There is a lot of flaky and crumbly rock on the climb that would mostly clean with traffic, but there is an alarming, massive horn in the roof break that feels paper thin.

Three-star movement on one-star rock.
content.location: Center of the main face, just right of the newly bolted "Big Fish" project and left of "Roman Cadillac Church" 12+.

content.description: Start up the right-trending crack, then head straight up the face past a few bolts. Another right-trending crack past another bolt (crux) will take you to the anchors.
content.location: Lone route on the lowest buttress and the first route that you'll reach on the approach.

content.description:
Diagonal out right on an incut rail system, with a big crux span passing the 3rd bolt. The rest of the route is generally big moves between big holds but stays on you, as the wall is deceptively steep.

This thing is still pretty crunchy and could use some traffic, and in general, the rock isn't Donner's finest. Good movement though.
content.protection: 6 bolts, chain anchors. Stick clipping the first bolt (or two) wouldn't be a bad idea.
content.location: Right-most of two routes on the far left side of the crag, just left of the obvious large slab.

content.description: Cool slab that gets progressively harder, with a crux move between the last bolt and the anchors. Good foot positioning will help as the holds peter out. Choose your crystals wisely!
content.location: Far right side of the crag, just right of the obvious arete of "Sink Or Swim".

content.description: Romp up a right-trending ramp for a few bolts, then launch up the steepening face via small edges, sidepulls, and shallow dishes. Bring those steel tendons!
content.location: Left-most route on the main/upper wall. If looking at the Horniak guide, it goes through the yellow swath of rock to the left of "The Gods Must Be Lazy".
